Strange question -- if you are reading Harry Potter in Chinese, you must be quite proficient in Chinese already.  I'm sure you don't need to have everything spelt out in Pinyin then.  Kaiser Kuo has provided a very comprehensive list of names, so I will restrict my answer to a general discussion of principle. A few examples, with the Pinyin romanization in parentheses: Harry Potter  哈利·波特 (Hali Bote)Hermione Granger 赫敏·格兰杰 (Hemin Gelanjie)Ron Weasley 罗恩·韦斯莱 (Luo'en Weisilai)Albus Dumbledore 阿不思·邓布利多 (Abusi Dengbuliduo)Voldemort 伏地魔 (Fudimo) As is common when names are translated from Western languages into Chinese, the Chinese names are largely transliterations.  In other words, the Chinese characters are chosen primarily for their pronunciation, which, when strung together, constitute a loose approximation of how the name sounds in the original language.  The meaning of the characters chosen is largely irrelevant. For example, Harry becomes Ha-li and Albus become A-bu-si.  Although the meanings of the characters is irrelevant, for the most part the characters chosen have a generally positive connotation to avoid any sort of negative double meaning.  To use the example of Harry, ha means "laughter" and li means "benefit".  It would be inappropriate, however, to interpret this as meaning "to benefit from laughter" or something similar.  In this case, double meanings are usually unintended. In some cases, however, characters can be chosen that both approximate the pronunciation and carry some meaning.  Take Voltemort 伏地魔 (fu-di-mo) for example: the mo 魔 character literally means "evil spirit" or "devil", so this could be interpreted as the "Fu-di Devil".  It is safe to say that this name would not have been translated into Chinese the same way if Voldemort were a positive character. So, sometimes the way Chinese names are derived can be a clever combination of both transliteration and interpretation. As demonstrated by Kenny Kao's answer, character names may be different in Taiwan (or Hong Kong & Singapore, for that matter).  However, regardless of one's political views, these days it's common to accept the Mainland Chinese standard as the international standard. A complete list of character names with links to detailed descriptions in Chinese can be found at Baidu Baike 百度百科：http://baike.baidu.com/view/18045.htm?subLemmaId=4953140&fromenter=%B9%FE%C0%FB%B2%A8%CC%D8。
